awd_titl_txt: Overcoming plasmonic loss to realize high performance telecommunication devices
awd_abstract_narration:
Non Technical Abstract:
Today, optical technologies are the backbone of our information society, empowering impactful services such as virtual medical consultations, access to data stored in the cloud, and energy-efficient high-performance computing in largescale datacenters. Photonic solutions are particularly suited to enable these services due to the advantages of light such as multi-terabit bandwidths, low-loss propagation over kilometers, and low cross-talk. In fact, some internet provides have begun providing service entirely through light (fiber optics). As a result, the advancement of photonic telecommunications technologies will have a profound impact upon our nation by providing improved performance of internet-based services, reduced energy consumption, and a lower cost of construction/operation for networks. Current photonic modulators, small switches which convert electrical signals into optical pulses, are limited in their speed due to the weak interaction of light and matter. More recently, metals have been utilized to enhance this interaction, facilitating a reduction of device size and increase of speed. Yet, these devices struggle to achieve efficient transmission ~10%, which is simply insufficient for many applications. Here, we look utilize the benefits of both approaches by allowing the lossy metallic nature to be engaged and disengaged when desired. This approach limits the loss of the structure while still maintaining the benefits of metal plasmonic structures. By partnering with existing programs at the home university, the research will provide avenues for local high school students, teachers, and undergraduates to learn about impact of light-based technologies on our society while providing a platform to train a highly skilled workforce. 

Technical Abstract:
Despite significant research in the areas of photonic and plasmonic-based approaches, there is yet to be a device which achieves efficient all-around performance (modulation strength, insertion loss, energy consumption, size, and speed). Photonic approaches suffer from poor light-matter interactions, requiring speed restricting resonators and long interaction lengths, while plasmonic approaches have yet to overcome the large insertion loss associated with their metallic components. This proposal seeks to solve this dilemma through a new design approach in which plasmonic elements are disengaged in the off- (transmissive) state to minimize insertion loss, yet are engaged in the on-state to achieve large modulation in a short distance. This is achieved through a specifically chosen set of oxide layers which appear dielectric to the optical mode under no electrical bias, yet can be modulated into an epsilon-near-zero condition (effectively engaging the plasmonic nature) to achieve efficient modulation through free-carrier accumulation and depletion. It is shown that this approach is able to produce the first modulator design capable of efficient all-around performance: area of 3 square microns, 1.5 dB, 9dB extinction ratio, 12 fJ/bit energy consumption, and 112 GHz bandwidth. Although it is impactful for integrated systems, the approach is general and may also find applications in related areas such as metamaterials and sensors. Additionally, the realization of the device will demonstrate that plasmonic systems are not synonymous with loss and the benefits of such systems (confinement, enhanced light-matter-interaction) can be employed without detrimental loss.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Data and energy consumption of data centers is forecasted to increase at an exponential rate as services such as cloud computing, streaming, and artificial intelligence become mainstream. This leads to immense stress on the currently limited transmission systems in datacenters. The potential of multi-terabit per second transfer speeds along with loss cross talk and low propagation losses make photonic solutions well suited to address this issue. However, it can be difficult to control light and this often limits the speed and increases energy consumption of optical modulators (devices that encode data onto light). Plasmonic modulators, which utilize the coupling of light to metal, can improve these limits and lead to faster speeds and lower energy consumption at the cost of high losses (sometimes as much as 90%). This proposal sought to reduce the losses while enhancing efficiency and bandwidth of optical modulators by engineering a device design that enabled the lossy plasmonic component to be engaged and disengaged as desired - a plasmon-assisted structure.

The effort achieved this through the modulation of electron density in transparent conducting oxides such as aluminum doped zinc oxide and indium doped tin oxide. By applying a voltage near these materials, electrons can be attracted into a thin layer which creates a high density of electrons near the surface, forming a layer called epsilon-near-zero. This layer, which acts as a metal due to its high density of electrons, is lossy and is effective at absorbing light. However, upon the removal of the voltage the electrons disperse, and the material returns to its non-metal state with low optical absorption.

Intellectual Merit:

The effort highlighted a common misconception within the community, that this metallic layer is up to 5 nanometers thick. Simulations conducted showed that this is not true, and the layer is in fact 1 nanometer in thickness or less. Thus, it had minimal effect on optical loss when layered over a conventional waveguide. To counteract this, we proposed a slot waveguide geometry embedded with the transparent conducting material and explored the performance tradeoffs of the design and highlighted the key role of optical loss. Many prior works arbitrarily assumed a very low loss of the film that had not been shown. When using realistic loss values it is much more challenging to achieve the desired performance. Our efforts outlined these limitations and proposed potential design options to counteract them.

The next effort saw the optimization of growth of aluminum doped zinc oxide films using a low temperature process that is compatible with semiconductor fabrication. The effort achieved the record low optical loss of these films. However, a loss floor was discovered (not yet seen) which is believed to originate from defect during the material’s deposition.

Finally, the work concluded with testing of prototype devices achieving losses 3-4x less than typical plasmonic systems, becoming comparable to photonic systems. This was achieved while maintaining modulation levels similar to photonic systems but in a significantly smaller footprint. As a result, our efforts demonstrated the ability of plasmon-assisted designs to achieve leading performance across all metrics and highlighted key challenges in film loss and accumulation region thickness that will guide future developments.

Broader Impacts:

The effort was highly effective in the training and integration of students. The effort has supported the Vertically Integrated Projects team at VCU, which was expanded to 9 students, including the launch of the Telecommunications sub team. High-school and undergraduate researchers were also actively engaged throughout the duration of the project. In total the effort has involved more than 15 participants and directly generated 1 PhD graduate and 1 MS graduate.

The program generated two highly qualified and trained engineers in the areas of nanofabrication and integrated photonics which are essential fields to the CHIPS and Science Act. Specifically, their experience in integrated photonics is critical to the expansion of technologies to support the growth of AI at scale in large data centers via optical interconnects. The current program has directly provided support to train and develop these students which has in turn supported the talent gap in strategic areas of US interest and both graduates are pursuing employment with US and strategic ally semiconductor organizations.

Finally, undergraduate and high school students joined an international effort to translate a data table of Post 2000 measurements in nonlinear optical materials, published as static data tables, into a digital data table that is fully interactive and searchable. The effort included the nonlinear materials of relevance to this program including transparent conducting oxides and silicon among many others, both in bulk, and on-chip form. Through this, students were exposed to the nonlinear properties of materials, and a wide variety of measurement techniques/platforms. The resulting experience provided unique insights into the world of optics and photonics, and provided an opportunity for real-world impact to the academic community.
